attributes.comment:
I agree to the proposed increase of immigration fees under all but one condition: it
should concur with a reasonable improvement in the efficiency of immigration
processing. Every immigration attorney and their clients can testify that
immigration application is a long, stressful and frustrating process. For instance,
After PERM is in place, time needed for labor certification is shortened, but the
saved time is more than consumed by the long waiting period for I-485 submission
because visa bulletin has replaced LC as the bottleneck. I understand there is
quota constraint (for Chinese and Indians) here, but I can not help wondering if the
authority can do a better job streamlining the process of handling applications in
the pipeline. What percentage of increase in efficiency are immigration officials
committed to making within their power to improve their services for the public
while they ask for an average of 66% increase in fees? This is the question for
which I do want to
have an answer from you.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Hamlet Hua
